title: scale_duke_continuous
code: plot <- ggplot2::ggplot(palmerpenguins::penguins, ggplot2::aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm)) +   ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(colour = bill_length_mm)) +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Bill Length vs. Flipper Length", caption = "There are three different species of penguins.", x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Flipper Length (mm)")  plot + scale_duke_continuous() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

title: scale_duke_discrete_vignette
text: visualization, use R dummy data set palmerpenguins.
code: #install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(duke) library(ggplot2) library(ggmosaic) attach(penguins)

title: scale_duke_discrete_vignette
code: plot <- ggplot(palmerpenguins::penguins, aes(x=species, fill = species)) +   geom_bar() +   labs(title = "Distribution of Penguin Species", caption = "(Colors from left to right) \n Duke Royal Blue, Duke Navy Blue, Copper", x = "Species", y = "Count") +   theme(legend.position = "none")  plot +   scale_duke_discrete()

title: scale_duke_discrete_vignette
text: ## Using scale_duke_discrete() scatter plots ## Using scale_duke_discrete() histogram plots
code:
plot2 <- ggplot(data = palmerpenguins::penguins) +   ggmosaic::geom_mosaic(aes(x=product(sex, island), fill = sex)) +   labs(title = "Penguin Sex vs. Island", x = "Island", y = "Penguin Sex", caption = "(Color from top to bottom) 
 Granite, Duke Navy Blue, Duke Royal Blue")  plot2 +   scale_duke_discrete() #> Warning: `unite_()` was deprecated in tidyr 1.2.0. #> ℹ Please use `unite()` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the ggmosaic package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/haleyjeppson/ggmosaic>. #> New names: #> • `colour` -> `colour...1` #> • `colour` -> `colour...3` plot3 <- ggplot(palmerpenguins::penguins, aes(x=bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +   geom_point(aes(color = species)) +   labs(title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth", caption = "(Colors used) 
 Duke Royal Blue, Duke Navy Blue, Copper", x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Bill Depth (mm)")  plot3 +    scale_duke_discrete() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). #> New names: #> • `colour` -> `colour...1` #> • `colour` -> `colour...3` plot4 <- ggplot2::ggplot(palmerpenguins::penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +   geom_histogram(ggplot2::aes(fill = species), alpha = 0.8) +   labs(title = "Distribution of Penguin Body Mass", caption = "(Colors used) 
 Duke Royal Blue, Duke Navy Blue, Copper", x = "Body Mass (g)", y = "Count")  plot4 + scale_duke_discrete() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_bin()`). #> New names: #> • `colour` -> `colour...1` #> • `colour` -> `colour...3`

title: Authors and Citation
text: Aidan Gildea. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gildea (2023). duke: Makes color blind friendly visualizations Duke's official colors. https://github.com/aidangildea/duke, https://aidangildea.github.io/duke/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {duke: Makes color blind friendly visualizations with Duke's official colors},   author = {Aidan Gildea},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/aidangildea/duke, https://aidangildea.github.io/duke/}, }

title: Makes color blind friendly visualizations with Duke's official colors
text: goal duke generate visualizations Duke’s official suite colors color blind friendly way. package integrated ggplot2 visualization tools.

title: Makes color blind friendly visualizations with Duke's official colors
code: # Install duke directly: install.packages("duke")  # Or alternatively, install development version from GitHub # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("aidangildea/duke")

title: Makes color blind friendly visualizations with Duke's official colors
text: package fully integrated ggplot2, therefore, allows customize several visualization features. adding aesthetic functions theme_duke() scale_color_duke() visualizations, can easily implement Duke official colors color blind friendly way. information use ggplot2, please visit GitHub repository.

title: Makes color blind friendly visualizations with Duke's official colors
text: First, create standard ggplot2 visualization. example, use scatter plot.  , simply convert visualization Duke official colors calling theme_duke().
code: library(ggplot2) library(duke) plot <- ggplot2::ggplot(iris, ggplot2::aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width)) +   ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(colour = Species)) +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Title", caption = "Caption", x = "X Var", y = "Y Var")  plot plot + theme_duke()

title: Makes color blind friendly visualizations with Duke's official colors
text: questions package use, please reach Aidan Gildea aidan.gildea@duke.edu.

title: Duke Palette Function — duke_pal
text: Duke Palette Function

title: Duke Palette Function — duke_pal
code: duke_pal()

title: Duke Palette Function — duke_pal
text: Character vector Duke palette hex codes.

title: Duke Palette Function — duke_pal
code: duke_pal() #> function (n)  #> { #>     n_values <- length(values) #>     if (n > n_values) { #>         warning("This manual palette can handle a maximum of ",  #>             n_values, " values. You have supplied ", n, ".",  #>             call. = FALSE) #>     } #>     unname(values[seq_len(n)]) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x55578cafe4a0> #> <environment: 0x55578cafdb38> #> attr(,"max_n") #> [1] 8

title: Apply continuous color scale — scale_duke_continuous
text: Apply continuous color scale

title: Apply continuous color scale — scale_duke_continuous
code: scale_duke_continuous(   ...,   low = "#E2E6ED",   high = "#00539B",   space = "Lab",   na.value = "#B5B5B5",   guide = "colourbar",   aesthetics = c("colour", "color") )

title: Apply continuous color scale — scale_duke_continuous
text: ... Arguments passed continuous_scale. low Low end color gradient. high High end color gradient. space Color space calculate gradient. na.value Color used NA values. guide Type legend. "colorbar" continuous scale, "legend" discrete scale. aesthetics String vector strings detailing aesthetic features continuous scale can apply .

title: Apply continuous color scale — scale_duke_continuous
text: visualization continuous duke color scale

title: Apply continuous color scale — scale_duke_continuous
code: # Default example from Hatteras to Duke Royal Blue plot3 <- ggplot2::ggplot(iris, ggplot2::aes(x=Petal.Length, y = Petal.Width)) +   ggplot2::geom_point() plot3 + scale_duke_continuous()

code: #' # Default example plot3 <- ggplot2::ggplot(iris, ggplot2::aes(x=Species, fill = Species)) + ggplot2::geom_bar() plot3 + scale_duke_discrete() #> New names: #> • `colour` -> `colour...1` #> • `colour` -> `colour...3`

title: Theme Duke — theme_duke
text: Theme Duke

title: Theme Duke — theme_duke
code: theme_duke(   base_size = 11,   base_family = "",   base_line_size = base_size/22,   base_rect_size = base_size/22 )

title: Theme Duke — theme_duke
text: base_size base size base_family base family base_line_size baseline size base_rect_size base rect

title: Theme Duke — theme_duke
text: plot Duke colors

title: Theme Duke — theme_duke
code: plot <- ggplot2::ggplot(cars, ggplot2::aes(speed, dist)) + ggplot2::geom_point() + ggplot2::labs(title = "Duke Blue") plot + theme_duke() #> Warning: Garamond 3 LT Std is not available on your system.
